plausible_answers.text: A Footnote to History: Eight Years of Trouble in Samoa, "

qas.question: What work was written by John Williams about the people of Samoa?

context: <b5_0>Mission work<b5_0/> in Samoa had begun in late 1830 by <a0_0>John Williams<a0_0/>, of <b6_0>the <a1_0>London Missionary Society<b6_0/><a1_0/> arriving in Sapapali'i from The Cook Islands and Tahiti. According to Barbara A. West, "The Samoans were also known to engage in <b7_0>‘<a2_0>headhunting<a2_0/>'<b7_0/>, a ritual of war in which a warrior took the head of his slain opponent to give to his leader, thus proving his bravery." However, <a3_0>Robert Louis Stevenson<a3_0/>, who lived in Samoa from 1889 until his death in <a4_0><b8_0>1894<b8_0/><a4_0/>, wrote in <b9_0>A Footnote to History: Eight Years of Trouble in Samoa, "<b9_0/>… the Samoans are gentle people."
